{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3551364,"name":"Devin Lee","username":"codeduck101","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/codeduck101/{size}/253970_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-08T20:15:38.676Z","cooked":"

We first noticed that our drivetrain was demanding ~4 volts during the Pinnacles Regional. Citrus helped us circumvent this by changing kSpeedAt12Volts (in Phoenix Tuner’s TunerConstants.java file) from 5.15 m/s to 15.25 m/s, which demands about 12 volts when the left joystick is fully tilted. This behavior is similar to what happens on our test rig, which lacks everything except for a drivetrain.

I have already tried searching here, but I did not find a solution. If there is already a solution out there, that’d be appreciated too.

I notice that this is suspiciously similar to a feet-to-meters conversion issue, but I’m not sure where that would be happening in our code. Below is information about our robot and our code.

We are using WCP’s Swerve X Flipped for our test rig and their Swerve X2i for our competition robot. I recorded the below data on our test rig, and the repository provided is used solely on our test rig. (The main difference is the TunerConstants.java file due to the differing drivetrains.)

I cannot upload attachments because I am a new user, but I ran the test rig on a stand to put together an AdvantageKit log file. Here’re a few images of that file’s odometry outputs:

image1598×1023 53.8 KB

image1600×1023 58.4 KB

image1604×1020 50.8 KB

Here’s a link to the repository and branch that I used to gather that data:

github.com

GitHub - TeamVortechs/9999-PRACTICE-ROBOT-3257-2025-Reefscape at...

devin/9999-command-autonomous

9999 PRACTICE ROBOT CODE ONLY. Contribute to TeamVortechs/9999-PRACTICE-ROBOT-3257-2025-Reefscape development by creating an account on GitHub.

Thanks for helping.

It looks like you might be using closed-loop control on the drive motors, in which case you need to tune your drive gains. I believe that unlike our swerve API, AdvantageKit uses wheel rotations instead of motor rotations, so you need to at a minimum scale up those gains by your gear ratio (so kV would be 0.694, for example).
